Clementi Dipartimento di Matematica, Università di Roma ”Tor Vergata”, Email: clementi@mat.uniroma2.it.    Angelo Monti Contact Author: Dipartimento di Scienze dell’Informazione, Università “La Sapienza” di Roma, Email: monti@dsi.uniroma1.it.    Riccardo Silvestri Contact Author: Dipartimento di Scienze dell’Informazione, Università “La Sapienza” di Roma, Email: silver@dsi.uniroma1.it.
Abstract

A multi-hop synchronous wirelss network is said to be unknown if the nodes have no knowledge of the topology. A basic task in wireless network is that of broadcasting a message (created by a fixed source node) to all nodes of the network. Typical operations in real-life wireless networks is the multi-broadcast that consists in performing a set of r𝑟ritalic_r independent broadcasts. The study of broadcast operations on unknown wireless network is started by the seminal paper of Bar-Yehuda et al [BGI87] and has been the subject of several recent works.

In this paper, we study the completion and the termination time of distributed protocols for both the (single) broadcast and the multi-broadcast operations on unknown networks as functions of the number of nodes n𝑛nitalic_n, the maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D, the maximum in-degree ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ, and the congestion c𝑐citalic_c of the networks. We establish new connections between these operations and some combinatorial concepts, such as selective families, strongly-selective families (also known as superimposed codes), and pairwise r𝑟ritalic_r-different families. Such connections, combined with a set of new lower and upper bounds on the size of the above families, allow us to derive new lower bounds and new distributed protocols for the broadcast and multi-broadcast operations.

In particular, our upper bounds are almost tight and improve exponentially over the previous bounds when D𝐷Ditalic_D and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ are polylogarithmic in n𝑛nitalic_n. Network topologies having “small” eccentricity and “small” degree (such as bounded-degree expanders) are often used in practice to achieve efficient communication.

1 Introduction

1.1 Wireless networks

Static ad-hoc wireless networks (in short, radio networks) have been the subject of several works in recent years due to their potential applications in scenarios such as battlefields, emergency disaster relief, and in any situation in which it is very difficult (or impossible) to provide the necessary infrastructure [R96, WNE00]. As in other network models, a challenging task is to enable fast communication.

A radio network is a set of radio stations that are able to communicate by transmitting and receiving radio signals. A transmission range is assigned to each station s𝑠sitalic_s and any other station within this range can directly (i.e. by one hop) receive messages from s𝑠sitalic_s. Communication between two stations that are not within their respective ranges can be achieved by multi-hop transmissions. A useful (and sometimes unavoidable) paradigm of radio communication is the structuring of communication into synchronous time-slots. This paradigm is commonly adopted in the practical design of protocols and hence the use of the paradigm in theoretical analysis is well motivated [BGI87, G85, R72].

A radio network can be modeled as a directed graph where an edge (u,v)𝑢𝑣(u,v)( italic_u , italic_v ) exists if and only if u𝑢uitalic_u can communicate with v𝑣vitalic_v in one hop. The nodes of a radio network are processing units, each of which is able to perform local computations. It is also assumed that every node can perform any local computation required for deciding the next send/receive operation during the current time-slot. In every time-slot, each node can be active or non active. When active, it can decide to be either transmitter or receiver: in the former case the node transmits a message along all of its outgoing edges while, in the latter case, it tries to recover messages from all its incoming edges. When it is not active, it does not perform any kind of operation. The fundamental feature here is that a node v𝑣vitalic_v can recover a message from one of its incoming edges if and only if this edge is the only one bringing in a message. If two or more neighbors of a node are transmitting at the same time-slot then a collision occurs. Nodes do not distinguish between the background noise and the interference noise (i.e., we are in the case of absence of collision detection [PL95, BGI87]). A radio network is said to be unknown when every node knows nothing about the network but its own label [BGI87, CGGPR00, CGOR00, CGR00]. Informally speaking, unknown radio networks, with absence of collision detection, model communication networks with multi-access channels in which the assumptions on the processors’ knowledge and on the channel are minimal. In fact, in several applications, the network topology is unstable or dynamic and it is difficult to distinguish the presence of a collision from the background noise of the channel. Another important motivation in studying unknown networks comes from its strong connection with the fault-tolerance issue [PR97, KKP98, KM98, CMS01c]. Unknown networks can also be seen as “known” networks (i.e. networks in which nodes have the knowledge of the entire initial topology) with unknown permanent faults. A node (or an edge) is said to suffer a permanent fault if it is never active during the entire execution of the protocol [KKP98, CMS01c]. It is easy to show that a broadcast protocol for unknown fault-free networks is also an (unknown permanent-)fault tolerant protocol for general (known) networks and viceversa. So, the results obtained in the unknown model immediately apply to the permanent-fault tolerance issue.

One of the fundamental tasks in network communication is the broadcast operation. It consists in transmitting a message from one source node to all the nodes.

According to the network model described above, the communication protocol operates in time-slots: at every time-slot, each active node decides to either transmit or receive, or turn into the non active state. Two kinds of broadcast protocols have been considered in the literature [BGI87, BD97, CGGPR00, CGOR00]: spontaneous protocols, in which the starting time-slot is known to all the nodes and, thus, every node can transmit even if it has not received any message in previous time-slots; non spontaneous protocols in which a node (which is not the source) may act as a transmitter in a time-slot only if it has received a message in some previous time-slots (while the source starts at time-slot 0). A deterministic (randomized) broadcast protocol is said to have completed broadcasting when all nodes, reachable from the source, have received (with high probability111A formal definition of completion time for randomized protocols will be given later.) the source message. Notice that when this happens, the nodes not necessarily stop to run the protocol since they might not know that the operation is completed. We also say that a broadcast protocol terminates in time t𝑡titalic_t if, after the time-slot t𝑡titalic_t, all the nodes are in the non active state (i.e. when all nodes stop to run the protocol).

The completion and termination time of Deterministic (Randomized) Broadcast protocols, in short DB (RB) protocols, will be analysed as functions of the following parameters of the network: the number n𝑛nitalic_n of nodes, the maximum in-degree ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ, and the maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D over all possible source nodes. Given a source node s𝑠sitalic_s, the eccentricity of s𝑠sitalic_s is the largest distance between s𝑠sitalic_s and any node of the network. Observe that the maximum eccentricity equals the diameter in the case of symmetric networks.

A typical task in real-life radio networks is that of performing a set of simultaneous and independent broadcast operations: a multi-broadcast operation is to perform r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1italic_r ≥ 1 broadcasts (from an arbitrary multiset of source nodes). The completion time of a Deterministic (Randomized) multi-Broadcast protocol, in short multi-DB (multi-RB) protocols, is defined as follows. A multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol on a radio network has completion time t𝑡titalic_t if, (with high probability) every broadcast message is received by all the nodes reachable from the source of the message within the first t𝑡titalic_t time-slots. The termination time of a multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol is defined as for DB protocols.

As for the channel bandwidth, we distinguish two models. In the Unbounded-Bandwidth (in short UB) model [CGR00], a node can send/receive messages of unbounded size (so, a node can send an arbitrary large subset of the r𝑟ritalic_r messages in one time-slot). In the Bounded-Bandwidth (in short BB) model [BII93], every node can send messages of size at most O⁢(log⁡n+log⁡r)𝑂𝑛𝑟O(\log n+\log r)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_r ) in one time-slot. In this model, the completion time of the protocols also depends on the congestion (denoted as c𝑐citalic_c) which is defined as the maximum number of broadcast messages that a node has to receive (where the maximum is computed over all possible nodes).

1.2 Previous results

Broadcast. Broadcasting in unknown radio networks has been introduced and studied in the seminal paper [BGI87] by Bar-Yehuda et al. They proved a lower bound Ω⁢(n)Ω𝑛\Omega(n)roman_Ω ( italic_n ) on the completion time of any DB protocol running on a family of unknown, symmetric radio networks of diameter 3. They also provide a non spontaneous RB protocol having expected completion time O((D+logn)logn))O((D+\log n)\log n))italic_O ( ( italic_D + roman_log italic_n ) roman_log italic_n ) ). Thus, the Bar-Yehuda et al’s work represents an important example in which randomized computations have been proved to be exponentially faster than deterministic ones. On the other hand, their randomized protocol does not terminate when no upper bound on n𝑛nitalic_n is known. In [ABLP89], a lower bound Ω⁢(log2⁡n)Ωsuperscript2𝑛\Omega(\log^{2}n)roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) is shown for RB protocols that holds even for graphs of constant eccentricity (and diameter). The best known general lower bound for RB protocols is Ω⁢(D⁢log⁡(n/D))Ω𝐷𝑛𝐷\Omega(D\log(n/D))roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_log ( italic_n / italic_D ) ), obtained in [KM93]. As for non spontaneous DB protocols, Bruschi and Del Pinto [BD97] obtained a lower bound Ω⁢(D⁢log⁡n)Ω𝐷𝑛\Omega(D\log n)roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_log italic_n ) for symmetric networks of diameter D𝐷Ditalic_D. Moreover, an equivalent lower bound for spontaneous DB protocols on directed networks has been proved by Chlebus et al [CGGPR00]. The first positive results on DB protocols in unknown radio networks have been presented in [DKKP99]; however, this paper only studies radio networks having restricted topologies. In [CGGPR00], a DB protocol for symmetric unknown networks is presented that has O⁢(n)𝑂𝑛O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) completion and termination time thus matching the lower bound in [BGI87], and a DB protocol for general unknown networks that has O⁢(n11/6)𝑂superscript𝑛116O(n^{11/6})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 11 / 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) completion and termination time. This protocol is the first one that makes an explicit use of selective families: as we will see later, such families play a crucial role in the techniques introduced in this paper.

By means of a better use of selective families, more efficient DB protocols have been obtained in [CGOR00]. They obtain a protocol having O⁢(n9/5)𝑂superscript𝑛95O(n^{9/5})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 9 / 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) completion and termination time; for networks of maximum in-degree Δ=O⁢(na)Δ𝑂superscript𝑛𝑎\Delta=O(n^{a})roman_Δ = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), they obtain O⁢(n1+a+H⁢(a)+o⁢(1))𝑂superscript𝑛1𝑎𝐻𝑎𝑜1O(n^{1+a+H(a)+o(1)})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_a + italic_H ( italic_a ) + italic_o ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) completion and termination time (where H⁢(a)𝐻𝑎H(a)italic_H ( italic_a ) denotes the binary entropy function). They also present a DB protocol having O⁢(n3/2)𝑂superscript𝑛32O(n^{3/2})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) completion and termination time and a DB protocol having O⁢(n⁢Δ2⁢log3⁡n/log⁡(Δ⁢log⁡n))𝑂𝑛superscriptΔ2superscript3𝑛Δ𝑛O(n\Delta^{2}\log^{3}n/\log(\Delta\log n))italic_O ( italic_n roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log ( roman_Δ roman_log italic_n ) ) completion time working on unknown networks of maximum in-degree ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ.

The best presently known deterministic upper bound for general unknown networks is O⁢(n⁢log2⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript2𝑛O(n\log^{2}n)italic_O ( italic_n roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) and is obtained by means of a not efficiently constructible DB protocol introduced by Chrobak et al in [CGR00].

It thus turns out that all previous deterministic upper bounds are superlinear (in n𝑛nitalic_n) independently of the parameters D𝐷Ditalic_D and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ of the network. A simple analysis of such protocols show that they in fact runs in superlinear time even when D𝐷Ditalic_D and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ are bounded by a fixed constant. In several wireless network applications, network topologies with “small” diameter and “small” degree are typically adopted in order to achieve fast and reliable communication [AS92, Lei91, KR96]. It is thus natural and well-motivated to investigate the complexity of broadcast operations restricted to such topologies: the “hope” is to obtain protocols which run faster than the previous “general” protocols.

Multi-broadcast. As for the UB model, Chrobak et al [CGR00] provide a multi-DB protocol for the gossiping operation (i.e., the special case of n𝑛nitalic_n simultaneous broadcast operations, each starting from one different node) that has O⁢(n3/2)𝑂superscript𝑛32O(n^{3/2})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) completion time. Multi-broadcast in the BB model has been studied in [BII93], where a randomized distributed protocol is presented that performs the broadcast of r𝑟ritalic_r messages in O⁢((D+r)⁢log⁡Δ⁢log⁡n)𝑂𝐷𝑟Δ𝑛O((D+r)\log\Delta\log n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_r ) roman_log roman_Δ roman_log italic_n ) completion time. However, this protocol does not work on unknown networks: it indeed assumes that every node knows its respective neighborhood and that the network is symmetric. Moreover, it requires a set-up phase in which a Breadh First Search tree is computed in O⁢((n+D⁢log⁡n)⁢log⁡Δ)𝑂𝑛𝐷𝑛ΔO((n+D\log n)\log\Delta)italic_O ( ( italic_n + italic_D roman_log italic_n ) roman_log roman_Δ ) time-slots.

1.3 Our results

Broadcast. Our first contribution is the construction of a family of graphs that yields an Ω⁢(n⁢log⁡D)Ω𝑛𝐷\Omega(n\log D)roman_Ω ( italic_n roman_log italic_D ) lower bound on the completion time of DB protocols on unknown networks. The above result applies to both spontaneous protocols on directed networks and non spontaneous protocols on symmetric networks. The lower bound given in [CGGPR00] and [BD97] (i.e. Ω⁢(D⁢log⁡n)Ω𝐷𝑛\Omega(D\log n)roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_log italic_n )) improves over the linear lower bound given in [BGI87] for D≥3𝐷3D\geq 3italic_D ≥ 3 only when D𝐷Ditalic_D is “almost” linear, i.e., D=ω⁢(n/log⁡n)𝐷𝜔𝑛𝑛D=\omega(n/\log n)italic_D = italic_ω ( italic_n / roman_log italic_n ). Instead, our lower bound implies a superlinear number of time-slots for any D=ω⁢(1)𝐷𝜔1D=\omega(1)italic_D = italic_ω ( 1 ) and, moreover, it implies that the O⁢(n⁢log2⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript2𝑛O(n\log^{2}n)italic_O ( italic_n roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) deterministic upper bound given in [CGR00] is almost optimal when D=Ω⁢(nα)𝐷Ωsuperscript𝑛𝛼D=\Omega(n^{\alpha})italic_D = roman_Ω ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for any constant α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0. We emphasize that our lower bound also holds when every node knows n𝑛nitalic_n and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. A simple variant of our family of graphs allows us to get the first lower bound that also depends on ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ: we indeed provide an Ω⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ))Ω𝐷Δ𝑛Δ\Omega(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) ) lower bound that holds for any Δ≤n/DΔ𝑛𝐷\Delta\leq n/Droman_Δ ≤ italic_n / italic_D. This lower bound implies that the bound O⁢(n⁢log2⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript2𝑛O(n\log^{2}n)italic_O ( italic_n roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) given in [CGR00] is almost optimal whenever D⁢Δ=Ω⁢(n)𝐷ΔΩ𝑛D\Delta=\Omega(n)italic_D roman_Δ = roman_Ω ( italic_n ).

On the other hand, we provide a new broadcast technique that yields the first (non constructive) DB protocols having a completion-time that does not contain n𝑛nitalic_n as linear factor but only D𝐷Ditalic_D and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. More precisely, we obtain an O⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ)⁢log1+α⁡n)𝑂𝐷Δ𝑛Δsuperscript1𝛼𝑛O(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta)\log^{1+\alpha}n)italic_O ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) upper bound, where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is any fixed real positive constant.

Our protocols are thus not efficient when D⁢Δ=ω⁢(n⁢poly⁢log⁡n)𝐷Δ𝜔𝑛poly𝑛D\Delta=\omega(n{\rm poly}\log n)italic_D roman_Δ = italic_ω ( italic_n roman_poly roman_log italic_n ). However, by comparing them with our Ω⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ))Ω𝐷Δ𝑛Δ\Omega(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) ) lower bound, we can see that these upper bounds are almost optimal when Δ=O⁢(n/D)Δ𝑂𝑛𝐷\Delta=O(n/D)roman_Δ = italic_O ( italic_n / italic_D ). This solves an open problem posed in [CGOR00]. Furthermore, when D,Δ=O⁢(poly⁢log⁡n)𝐷Δ𝑂poly𝑛D,\Delta=O({\rm poly}\log n)italic_D , roman_Δ = italic_O ( roman_poly roman_log italic_n ), this is an exponential improvement over the superlinear (in n𝑛nitalic_n) completion time obtained by the best previously known (not efficietly constructible) DB protocols [CGR00].

Another interesting consequence lies in a new insight into the real gap between randomization and determinism in radio broadcasting. Indeed, rather surprisingly, if we compare our deterministic upper bounds to the O⁢((D+log⁡n)⁢log⁡n)𝑂𝐷𝑛𝑛O((D+\log n)\log n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + roman_log italic_n ) roman_log italic_n ) upper bound obtained by the Bar-Yehuda et al’s RD protocol [BGI87], we can easily state that the exponential gap between deterministic protocols and randomized ones holds, at least from a theoretical view point, only for radio networks having “large” maximum in-degree (i.e. when Δ=Ω⁢(nβ)ΔΩsuperscript𝑛𝛽\Delta=\Omega(n^{\beta})roman_Δ = roman_Ω ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), for some β>0𝛽0\beta>0italic_β > 0).

Multi-broadcast. Let us first consider the BB model. By combining the trivial lower bound Ω⁢(D)Ω𝐷\Omega(D)roman_Ω ( italic_D ) with the fact that a node cannot receive more than one message per time-slot, it is easy to derive an Ω⁢(D+c)Ω𝐷𝑐\Omega(D+c)roman_Ω ( italic_D + italic_c ) lower bound for the multi-broadcast operation for both randomized and deterministic protocols (observe that, in the UB model, we can only get Ω⁢(D)Ω𝐷\Omega(D)roman_Ω ( italic_D ) since the congestion c𝑐citalic_c is always 1111). On the other hand, we are not aware of any lower bound of the form Ω⁢(f⁢(c)⋅g⁢(n))Ω⋅𝑓𝑐𝑔𝑛\Omega(f(c)\cdot g(n))roman_Ω ( italic_f ( italic_c ) ⋅ italic_g ( italic_n ) ) where both f𝑓fitalic_f and g𝑔gitalic_g are some unbounded functions. Such a kind of lower bounds is important since it implies that a “perfect pipeline” protocol (i.e., a protocol yielding an O⁢(S⁢B⁢(D,n)+c)𝑂𝑆𝐵𝐷𝑛𝑐O(SB(D,n)+c)italic_O ( italic_S italic_B ( italic_D , italic_n ) + italic_c ) upper bound, where S⁢B⁢(D,n)𝑆𝐵𝐷𝑛SB(D,n)italic_S italic_B ( italic_D , italic_n ) is the best upper bound available for the broadcast operation) is not achievable. We provide the first lower bound of the kind defined above, even under very restrictive topology conditions. We indeed derive a family of graphs with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2roman_Δ = 2 that forces any multi-DB protocol to perform at least Ω⁢(c+(clog⁡c+D)⁢log⁡n)Ω𝑐𝑐𝑐𝐷𝑛\Omega(c+(\frac{c}{\log c}+D)\log n)roman_Ω ( italic_c + ( divide start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_c end_ARG + italic_D ) roman_log italic_n ) time-slots to complete multi-broadcast operations. Then, we derive an Ω⁢(c+clog⁡c⁢log⁡n+D⁢log⁡nD)Ω𝑐𝑐𝑐𝑛𝐷𝑛𝐷\Omega(c+\frac{c}{\log c}\log n+D\log\frac{n}{D})roman_Ω ( italic_c + divide start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_c end_ARG roman_log italic_n + italic_D roman_log divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG ) lower bound to multi-RD protocols. Hence, perfect pipelining is not achievable even with the help of distributed random choices.

We observe that the above lower bounds also hold in presence of collision detection and when the nodes know n𝑛nitalic_n and/or ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ.

On the other hand, we combine a variant of our (single) broadcast technique with a suitable “local” scheduling (that solves the congestions arising inside every node) in order to get a multi-DB protocol for the BB model. This protocol has O⁢((D+c)⁢Δ2⁢log2+α⁡n)𝑂𝐷𝑐superscriptΔ2superscript2𝛼𝑛O((D+c)\Delta^{2}\log^{2+\alpha}n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_c ) roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 + italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) completion time (where α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is any fixed real positive constant) and it can be converted into an efficiently constructible one having O⁢((D+c)⁢Δ2⁢log3+α⁡n)𝑂𝐷𝑐superscriptΔ2superscript3𝛼𝑛O((D+c)\Delta^{2}\log^{3+\alpha}n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_c ) roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 + italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) completon time.

By comparing the above upper bounds with our deterministic lower bound, we have that our multi-DB protocols turn out to be “almost” optimal (i.e., only a polylogarithmic factor away from the lower bound) when Δ=O⁢(poly⁢log⁡n)Δ𝑂poly𝑛\Delta=O({\rm poly}\log n)roman_Δ = italic_O ( roman_poly roman_log italic_n ). We also emphasize that, for Δ=O⁢(1)Δ𝑂1\Delta=O(1)roman_Δ = italic_O ( 1 ), our deterministic upper bound is almost equivalent to the O⁢((D+r)⁢log⁡Δ⁢log⁡n)𝑂𝐷𝑟Δ𝑛O((D+r)\log\Delta\log n)italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_r ) roman_log roman_Δ roman_log italic_n ) randomized upper bound [BII93] in which it is even assumed that the network is symmetric and the nodes know their respective neighborhood.

As for the UB model, since arbitrary large concatenation of the messages inside a node can be sent along the outgoing edges, we can use a simpler version of our multi-DB protocols. In this version, the local scheduling is not required and, thus, we get an O⁢(D⁢Δ2⁢log2+α⁡n)𝑂𝐷superscriptΔ2superscript2𝛼𝑛O(D\Delta^{2}\log^{2+\alpha}n)italic_O ( italic_D roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 + italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) upper bound.

1.4 Organization of the paper

Section 2 provides an overview of the connections between the issue of radio broadcasting and some combinatorial concepts and results. In Section 3, the proofs of such combinatorial results are given. Section 4 describes the results on the broadcast operation. In Section 5, the results on the multi-broadcast operation are presented. Finally, Section 6 discusses the obtained results and proposes some open problems.

2 Adopted techniques and some new combinatorial results: an overview

The proofs of our upper and lower bounds exploit some new combinatorial results that we believe to have a per se interest. In this section, we provide a description of such results and we outline their connection with broadcast and multi-broadcast operations.

In [CGGPR00], Chlebus et al introduced the use of selective families in designing DB protocols in unknown networks. In what follows, the set {1,…,n}1…𝑛\{1,\ldots,n\}{ 1 , … , italic_n } is denoted as [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ].

Definition 2.1

Let n𝑛nitalic_n and k𝑘kitalic_k be any integers with k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq nitalic_k ≤ italic_n. A family ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F of subsets of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] is (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective if, for every non empty subset Z𝑍Zitalic_Z of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] such that |Z|≤k𝑍𝑘|Z|\leq k| italic_Z | ≤ italic_k, there is a set F𝐹Fitalic_F in ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F such that |Z∩F|=1𝑍𝐹1|Z\cap F|=1| italic_Z ∩ italic_F | = 1.

In fact, selective families can be used to design oblivious DB protocols. A protocol is oblivious when its actions can be scheduled in advance. Let ℱ={F1,…,Fm}ℱsubscript𝐹1…subscript𝐹𝑚{\cal F}=\{F_{1},\ldots,F_{m}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be an (n,Δ)𝑛Δ(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Δ )-selective family. Then, it is easy to define an oblivious DB protocol on a network of n𝑛nitalic_n nodes and maximum in-degree ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ (this protocol has been introduced in [CGGPR00, CGOR00]).

A node u𝑢uitalic_u transmits at time-slot t≤m𝑡𝑚t\leq mitalic_t ≤ italic_m iff it has received the source message (i.e. it is informed) and u∈Ft𝑢subscript𝐹𝑡u\in F_{t}italic_u ∈ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

During the execution of these m𝑚mitalic_m time-slots, thanks to the selective property of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, for each set of d≤Δ𝑑Δd\leq\Deltaitalic_d ≤ roman_Δ nodes, there is at least one time-slot in which only one of the nodes of the set can transmit. This guarantees that at least one non informed node gets informed. By iterating this process n𝑛nitalic_n times, the broadcast is completed. Thus the completion time of such DB protocol is n⁢|ℱ|𝑛ℱn|{\cal F}|italic_n | caligraphic_F |.

We prove that there exist (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective families of size O⁢(k⁢log⁡(n/k))𝑂𝑘𝑛𝑘O(k\log(n/k))italic_O ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_n / italic_k ) ). We also prove that this upper bound is optimal, that is, any (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-selective family has size Ω⁢(k⁢log⁡(n/k))Ω𝑘𝑛𝑘\Omega(k\log(n/k))roman_Ω ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_n / italic_k ) ). On one hand, such small selective families are combined with a new broadcast technique in order to obtain our DB protocols. On the other hand, the lower bound on the size of selective families allows us to obtain lower bounds on the completion time of DB protocols.

In designing multi-DB protocols, we introduce families of sets having a stronger selective property.

Definition 2.2

Let k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq nitalic_k ≤ italic_n. A family ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F of subsets of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] is (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-strongly-selective if for every subset Z𝑍Zitalic_Z of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] such that |Z|≤k𝑍𝑘|Z|\leq k| italic_Z | ≤ italic_k and for every element z∈Z𝑧𝑍z\in Zitalic_z ∈ italic_Z there is a set F𝐹Fitalic_F in ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F such that Z∩F={z}𝑍𝐹𝑧Z\cap F=\{z\}italic_Z ∩ italic_F = { italic_z }.

If we have at hand an (n,Δ+1)𝑛Δ1(n,\Delta+1)( italic_n , roman_Δ + 1 )-strongly-selective family ℱ={F1,…,Fm}ℱsubscript𝐹1…subscript𝐹𝑚{\cal F}=\{F_{1},\ldots,F_{m}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, then it is easy to define an oblivious multi-DB protocol for the UB model on a network of n𝑛nitalic_n nodes and maximum in-degree ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. A node u𝑢uitalic_u transmits (all the messages it knows) at time-slot t≤m𝑡𝑚t\leq mitalic_t ≤ italic_m iff u∈Ft𝑢subscript𝐹𝑡u\in F_{t}italic_u ∈ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the strongly-selective property of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, for each set X𝑋Xitalic_X of d≤Δ+1𝑑Δ1d\leq\Delta+1italic_d ≤ roman_Δ + 1 nodes and for each node u∈X𝑢𝑋u\in Xitalic_u ∈ italic_X, there is at least one time-slot in which only u𝑢uitalic_u transmits among the nodes in X𝑋Xitalic_X. This guarantees that every message reaches at least a new node during the m𝑚mitalic_m time-slots. By iterating this process n𝑛nitalic_n times the multi-broadcast is completed in n⁢|ℱ|𝑛ℱn|{\cal F}|italic_n | caligraphic_F | time-slots.

Similarly to our single DB protocol, our multibroadcast protocol exploits the existence and the construction of strongly-selective families of small size. Actually, strongly-selective families are a new appearance of a well-known notion. Let ℱ={F1,…,Fm}ℱsubscript𝐹1…subscript𝐹𝑚{\cal F}=\{F_{1},\ldots,F_{m}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be a family of subsets of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] and consider the matrix Mℱsuperscript𝑀ℱM^{{\cal F}}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of m𝑚mitalic_m rows and n𝑛nitalic_n columns where Mt,iℱsubscriptsuperscript𝑀ℱ𝑡𝑖M^{{\cal F}}_{t,i}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is set to 1 iff i∈Ft𝑖subscript𝐹𝑡i\in F_{t}italic_i ∈ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It turns out that ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F is an (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-strongly-selective family iff the or of any set of at most k𝑘kitalic_k columns of Mℱsuperscript𝑀ℱM^{{\cal F}}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT covers only the columns of the set. Hence the columns of Mℱsuperscript𝑀ℱM^{{\cal F}}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT form a superimposed code [KS64]. Superimposed codes are also known in combinatorics as cover free families [EFF85]. Our protocol uses the (n,k)𝑛𝑘(n,k)( italic_n , italic_k )-strongly-selective families of size O⁢(min⁡{n,k2⁢log⁡n})𝑂𝑛superscript𝑘2𝑛O(\min\{n,k^{2}\log n\})italic_O ( roman_min { italic_n , italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n } ) whose existence is proved in [EFF85]. This existence proof does not provide an efficient construction. However, efficient construction of such families can be found in [KS64]: in this case the size is O⁢(min⁡{n,k2⁢log2⁡n})𝑂𝑛superscript𝑘2superscript2𝑛O(\min\{n,k^{2}\log^{2}n\})italic_O ( roman_min { italic_n , italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n } ).

Since a lower bound on the size of strongly-selective families determines a lower bound on the completion time of our multi-broadcast technique, we have also investigated this combinatorial aspect. In [CR96], Chaudhuri and Radhakrishnan obtain a lower bound Ω⁢((k2/log⁡k)⁢log⁡n)Ωsuperscript𝑘2𝑘𝑛\Omega((k^{2}/\log k)\log n)roman_Ω ( ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / roman_log italic_k ) roman_log italic_n ) for sufficiently large k𝑘kitalic_k such k≤n1/3𝑘superscript𝑛13k\leq n^{1/3}italic_k ≤ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Our contribution here is the extension to every k𝑘kitalic_k of that bound, that is, Ω⁢(min⁡{n,(k2/log⁡k)⁢log⁡n})Ω𝑛superscript𝑘2𝑘𝑛\Omega(\min\{n,(k^{2}/\log k)\log n\})roman_Ω ( roman_min { italic_n , ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / roman_log italic_k ) roman_log italic_n } ). This implies that there are no significantly smaller strongly-selective families than those adopted by our protocols.

As in the case of selective families, we tried to exploit strongly-selective families to obtain good lower bounds on the completion time of multi-DB protocols. But we could not obtain anything better than the lower bound for single broadcast.

In the BB model, besides the interference problems, the bound on the channel bandwidth yields further delays due to the congestion inside the nodes of the network. We exploit this aspect to obtain a non trivial lower bound. Consider the following situation that can happen during the execution of a multi-broadcast protocol. There are n𝑛nitalic_n nodes each of them having r𝑟ritalic_r messages. They are not connected each other, and exactly two of them are the only in-neighbours of another node u𝑢uitalic_u. Thus, all the r𝑟ritalic_r messages can be received by u𝑢uitalic_u only if, for every pair of nodes and for each message, there is a time-slot in which exactly one of the nodes of the pair transmits that message and the other does not transmit anything. This suggests to introduce the following notion.

Definition 2.3

Two sequences x→normal-→𝑥\vec{x}over→ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG and y→normal-→𝑦\vec{y}over→ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG of equal length over the alphabet {0}∪[r]0delimited-[]𝑟\{0\}\cup[r]{ 0 } ∪ [ italic_r ] are r𝑟ritalic_r-different if for any z∈[r]𝑧delimited-[]𝑟z\in[r]italic_z ∈ [ italic_r ] there is a coordinate i𝑖iitalic_i for which {xi,yi}={z,0}subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑧0\{x_{i},y_{i}\}=\{z,0\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = { italic_z , 0 }.

From the situation described above, we will show that a protocol which performs any multi-broadcast operation on unknown networks within t𝑡titalic_t time-slots must yield a set of n𝑛nitalic_n pairwise r𝑟ritalic_r-different sequences of length not greater than t𝑡titalic_t. By combining this connection with a new lower bound on the length of such sequences, i.e. Ω⁢((r/log⁡r)⁢log⁡n)Ω𝑟𝑟𝑛\Omega((r/\log r)\log n)roman_Ω ( ( italic_r / roman_log italic_r ) roman_log italic_n ), we derive the lower bounds for the multi-broadcast operation on the BB model.

3 Combinatorial results

In what follows, we provide a lower bound on the size of selective families. To this aim, we make use of the notion of intersection free family

Definition 3.1

Let l≤k≤n𝑙𝑘𝑛l\leq k\leq nitalic_l ≤ italic_k ≤ italic_n. A family ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F of k𝑘kitalic_k-subsets of [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] is (n,k,l)𝑛𝑘𝑙(n,k,l)( italic_n , italic_k , italic_l )-intersection free if |F1∩F2|≠lsubscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2𝑙|F_{1}\cap F_{2}|\neq l| italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≠ italic_l for every F1subscript𝐹1F_{1}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F.

Roughly speaking, the intersection free property is somewhat “complementary” to the selectivity property we are using in this paper. So, even though an explicit mathematical connection between the two properties will be determined later, the reader can already imagine our interest in introducing the following result obtained by Frankl and Füredi.

4 Broadcast operations

4.1 The lower bounds

In this section, we show the existence of an infinite family of directed graphs that force any DB protocol to perform, in the worst-case, Ω⁢(n⁢log⁡D)Ω𝑛𝐷\Omega(n\log D)roman_Ω ( italic_n roman_log italic_D ) time-slots before completing a broadcast. Then, we provide a simple variant of this family of graphs yielding a lower bound that also depends on ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. Our lower bound holds for the UB model (and, thus, for the BB model too). We first formalize the notion of DB protocol according to [BGI87].

Definition 4.1

A Deterministic distributed Broadcast DB protocol P𝑃Pitalic_P is a protocol that works in time-slots (numbered 0,1,…01normal-…0,1,\ldots0 , 1 , …) according to the following rules.

  1. 1.

    In the initial time-slot a specified node (i.e. the source) transmits a message (called the source message).

  2. 2.

    In each time-slot, each node either acts as transmitter or as receiver or is non active.

  3. 3.

    A node receives a message in a time-slot if and only if it acts as receiver and exactly one of its i⁢n𝑖𝑛initalic_i italic_n-neighbors acts as transmitter in that time-slot.

  4. 4.

    The action of a node in a specific time-slot is a function of its own label, the number of the current time-slot t𝑡titalic_t, and the messages received during the previous time-slots.

Theorem 4.1

For any DB protocol P𝑃Pitalic_P, for any n𝑛nitalic_n and for any D≤n/6𝐷𝑛6D\leq n/6italic_D ≤ italic_n / 6, there exists an n𝑛nitalic_n-node directed graph GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D such that P𝑃Pitalic_P completes broadcasting on GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Ω⁢(n⁢log⁡D)normal-Ω𝑛𝐷\Omega(n\log D)roman_Ω ( italic_n roman_log italic_D ) time-slots. The lower bound holds even when every node knows n𝑛nitalic_n.

Proof. The graph GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a layered n𝑛nitalic_n-node graph with D+1𝐷1D+1italic_D + 1 levels L0,L1,…,LDsubscript𝐿0subscript𝐿1…subscript𝐿𝐷L_{0},L_{1},\ldots,L_{D}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; Level L0subscript𝐿0L_{0}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains only the source s𝑠sitalic_s, level Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has no more than ⌊n/(2⁢D)⌋𝑛2𝐷\lfloor n/(2D)\rfloor⌊ italic_n / ( 2 italic_D ) ⌋ nodes for j=1,…,D−1𝑗1…𝐷1j=1,\ldots,D-1italic_j = 1 , … , italic_D - 1 and, finally, the level LDsubscript𝐿𝐷L_{D}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all the remaining nodes. All nodes of Lj−1subscript𝐿𝑗1L_{j-1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have outgoing edges to all nodes in Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As we will see later, the actions specified by P𝑃Pitalic_P determine the node assignment in the levels j≥1𝑗1j\geq 1italic_j ≥ 1 in such a way that the protocol is forced to execute Ω⁢((n/D)⁢log⁡D)Ω𝑛𝐷𝐷\Omega((n/D)\log D)roman_Ω ( ( italic_n / italic_D ) roman_log italic_D ) time-slots in order to successfully transmit the source message between two consecutive levels. This assignment will be performed by induction on the levels.

From Theorem 3.3, there exists a constant c>0𝑐0c>0italic_c > 0 such that, if 2≤D≤n/62𝐷𝑛62\leq D\leq n/62 ≤ italic_D ≤ italic_n / 6, any (⌈n/2⌉,⌊n/(2⁢D)⌋)𝑛2𝑛2𝐷(\lceil n/2\rceil,\lfloor n/(2D)\rfloor)( ⌈ italic_n / 2 ⌉ , ⌊ italic_n / ( 2 italic_D ) ⌋ )-selective family must have size at least T𝑇Titalic_T, where T=⌊c⁢nD⁢log⁡D⌋𝑇𝑐𝑛𝐷𝐷T=\lfloor{c\frac{n}{D}\log D}\rflooritalic_T = ⌊ italic_c divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG roman_log italic_D ⌋.

Theorem 4.2

Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be a DB protocol. Then, for any n𝑛nitalic_n, for any D≤n/6𝐷𝑛6D\leq n/6italic_D ≤ italic_n / 6, and for any Δ≤n/Dnormal-Δ𝑛𝐷\Delta\leq n/Droman_Δ ≤ italic_n / italic_D, there exists an n𝑛nitalic_n-node directed graph GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D and in-degree bounded by Δnormal-Δ\Deltaroman_Δ such that P𝑃Pitalic_P completes broadcasting on GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Ω⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ))normal-Ω𝐷normal-Δ𝑛normal-Δ\Omega(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) ) time-slots. The lower bound holds even when every node knows n𝑛nitalic_n and Δnormal-Δ\Deltaroman_Δ.

Proof. The proof is based on the same construction of the proof of Theorem  4.1. The only difference is that, for every j=1,2,…⁢D−1𝑗12…𝐷1j=1,2,\ldots D-1italic_j = 1 , 2 , … italic_D - 1, level Ljsubscript𝐿𝑗L_{j}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT consists of at most ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ nodes and LDsubscript𝐿𝐷L_{D}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (consisting of all the remaining nodes) is connected to the previous level in such a way that the maximum in-degree is kept not larger than ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. □□\Box□

4.2 The upper bounds

This section provides a DB protocol for unknown networks. For case of exposition, we first describe the protocol that assume the knowledge of n𝑛nitalic_n and ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. Then, we show how to extend the same technique to the cases in which ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ and n𝑛nitalic_n are not known by the nodes.

The following protocol assumes the knowledge of ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ and n𝑛nitalic_n.

Description of Protocol broad-a⁢(n,Δ)broad-a𝑛normal-Δ\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Δ ). The protocol uses an (n,Δ)𝑛Δ(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Δ )-selective family ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F. It starts by setting all the nodes to the active state, and by let s𝑠sitalic_s transmit the source message. After the first time-slot, it turns s𝑠sitalic_s to the non active state. Then, it performs a sequence of consecutive identical phases. Let us fix an arbitrary ordering for the sets of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F; at time-slot j𝑗jitalic_j of phase i𝑖iitalic_i, each node v𝑣vitalic_v acts according to the following rule: v𝑣vitalic_v transmits the source message along its outgoing edges if and only if

  • 1)

    the label of v𝑣vitalic_v belongs to the j𝑗jitalic_j-th set of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, and

  • 2)

    v𝑣vitalic_v has received the source message for the first time during the phase i−1𝑖1i-1italic_i - 1.

After the phase in which a node v𝑣vitalic_v acts as a transmitter, it turns to the non active state (so, this is a first change w.r.t. the straightforward protocol described in Section 2). The active nodes that, at at time-slot j𝑗jitalic_j of any phase, have a state not satisfying Conditions (1)1(1)( 1 ) and (2)2(2)( 2 ) act as receivers. Observe that Condition (2)2(2)( 2 ) is the key difference between our technique and the straightforward one. As we will see in the analysis of the protocol, this difference will play a crucial role in order to achieve an upper bound not containing the linear factor n𝑛nitalic_n.

Theorem 4.3

Protocol broad-a⁢(n,Δ)broad-a𝑛normal-Δ\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Δ ) completes broadcasting and terminates in O⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ))𝑂𝐷normal-Δ𝑛normal-ΔO(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))italic_O ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) ) time-slots on any n𝑛nitalic_n-node graph of maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D and maximum in-degree Δnormal-Δ\Deltaroman_Δ.

Proof. Since, Theorem 3.1 implies that |ℱ|=O⁢(D⁢Δ⁢log⁡(n/Δ))ℱ𝑂𝐷Δ𝑛Δ|{\cal F}|=O(D\Delta\log(n/\Delta))| caligraphic_F | = italic_O ( italic_D roman_Δ roman_log ( italic_n / roman_Δ ) ), the thesis is an easy consequence of the following claim.

Claim. A node v𝑣vitalic_v receives (for the first time) the source message at phase i𝑖iitalic_i of protocol broad-a⁢(n,Δ)broad-a𝑛Δ\mbox{\sc broad-a}(n,\Delta)broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Δ ) if and only if v𝑣vitalic_v is at distance i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1 from the source s𝑠sitalic_s.
Proof. The proof is by induction on i𝑖iitalic_i. (⇐⇐\Leftarrow⇐). For i=0𝑖0i=0italic_i = 0 the Claim is obvious. We thus assume that all nodes at distance i𝑖iitalic_i have received the source message during phase i−1𝑖1i-1italic_i - 1. Let us consider a node v𝑣vitalic_v at distance i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1 during phase i𝑖iitalic_i. This node has at least one informed in-neighbor at distance i𝑖iitalic_i. According to the protocol, only the neighbors of v𝑣vitalic_v informed in phase i−1𝑖1i-1italic_i - 1 will act as transmitters in phase i𝑖iitalic_i. Then, from the (n,Δ)𝑛Δ(n,\Delta)( italic_n , roman_Δ )-selectivity of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, there will be a step of phase i𝑖iitalic_i, in which only one of these informed in-neighbors will transmit to v𝑣vitalic_v. (⇒⇒\Rightarrow⇒). If v𝑣vitalic_v is not at distance i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1 from s𝑠sitalic_s, then two cases may arise. If v𝑣vitalic_v is at distance less than i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1 then, by the inductive hypothesis, v𝑣vitalic_v has been informed before phase i𝑖iitalic_i. Otherwise, v𝑣vitalic_v is at distance greater than i+1𝑖1i+1italic_i + 1, so none of its in-neighbors has been informed before phase i𝑖iitalic_i.

□□\Box□

5 Multi-Broadcast: The BB model

We first need to extend Definition 4.1 to multi-broadcast operations. We assume here that each message has an header containing a unique ID number so that two messages have different ID numbers.

Definition 5.1

A multi-DB (multi-RB) protocol P𝑃Pitalic_P is a protocol that, given a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G and a set of r𝑟ritalic_r broadcast operations on it (in short, an r𝑟ritalic_r-broadcast operation, r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1italic_r ≥ 1), works in time-slots (numbered 0,1,…01normal-…0,1,\ldots0 , 1 , …) according to the following rules.

  1. 1.

    In every time-slot, each node either acts as transmitter or as receiver. When transmitting, the node sends one message.

  2. 2.

    All the nodes share the same message-recovering function ℛℛ{\cal R}caligraphic_R that takes any message m𝑚mitalic_m as input and, if any, returns the (unique) broadcast message contained in m𝑚mitalic_m.

  3. 3.

    A node receives a message in a time-slot if and only if it acts as receiver and exactly one of its i⁢n𝑖𝑛initalic_i italic_n-neighbors acts as transmitter in that time-slot.

  4. 4.

    The actions of a node in a specific time-slot are function of its own label, the number of the current time-slot t𝑡titalic_t, and the messages received during the previous time-slots (for multi-RB protocols, the actions also depend on the output of a random bit generators).

5.1 The lower bound for deterministic protocols

The next theorem provides a lower bound which is a function of the congestion c𝑐citalic_c and n𝑛nitalic_n.

Theorem 5.1

Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be any multi-DB protocol. Then, for any n≥4𝑛4n\geq 4italic_n ≥ 4 and c≥2𝑐2c\geq 2italic_c ≥ 2, there exist an n𝑛nitalic_n-node directed graph GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with D=3𝐷3D=3italic_D = 3, Δ=2normal-Δ2\Delta=2roman_Δ = 2, and an r𝑟ritalic_r-broadcast operation (with r≥c𝑟𝑐r\geq citalic_r ≥ italic_c) on GPsuperscript𝐺𝑃G^{P}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (yielding a congestion c𝑐citalic_c), such that P𝑃Pitalic_P completes this operation in Ω⁢((c/log⁡c)⁢log⁡n)normal-Ω𝑐𝑐𝑛\Omega((c/\log c)\log n)roman_Ω ( ( italic_c / roman_log italic_c ) roman_log italic_n ) time.

Any graph in 𝒢nsubscript𝒢𝑛{\cal G}_{n}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an n𝑛nitalic_n-nodes directed graph of 3 levels. Theorem 5.2

Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be any multi-DB protocol. Proof. Since a node can receive at most one message per time-slot, it is easy to obtain the lower bound Ω⁢(c)Ω𝑐\Omega(c)roman_Ω ( italic_c ). Then, by combining the family of graphs of Theorem  4.2 (with Δ=2Δ2\Delta=2roman_Δ = 2) with that yielding Theorem 5.1, we easily get the thesis. □□\Box□

Notice that the proof of Theorem 5.1 does not rely on the fact that the nodes do not know n𝑛nitalic_n. Thus, Theorem 5.2 also holds under this condition.

Finally, we observe that the above contruction can be easily modified in order to let each of the r𝑟ritalic_r broadcast messages start from a different source (i.e. we have r𝑟ritalic_r messages in r𝑟ritalic_r different sources). It suffices to replace the source node in 𝒢nsubscript𝒢𝑛{\cal G}_{n}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see the proof of Theorem 5.1) with the root of a binary directed tree in which the r𝑟ritalic_r sources are the leaves of the tree. The only difference is that D𝐷Ditalic_D is now a logarithmic function of n𝑛nitalic_n.

5.2 Lower bound for randomized protocols

Any worst-case time bound of a randomized protocol can be considered reliable if it happens within a high probability on every possible instance. This concept is widely adopted in the field of randomized algorithms [MR95], and it can be easily adapted to the case of multi-broadcast operations on unknown networks.

Definition 5.2

A multi-RB protocol P𝑃Pitalic_P has reliable completion time T𝑇Titalic_T (where, clearly, T𝑇Titalic_T depends on n𝑛nitalic_n) if, for any n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1italic_n ≥ 1 and for any n𝑛nitalic_n-node graph G𝐺Gitalic_G, P𝑃Pitalic_P completes, with probability at least 1−1/n11𝑛1-1/n1 - 1 / italic_n any r𝑟ritalic_r-broadcast operation on G𝐺Gitalic_G within T𝑇Titalic_T time-slots.

We first notice that, from Ineq. 10, there are at most (n−3)/2𝑛32(n-3)/2( italic_n - 3 ) / 2 different pairs in 𝒟¯¯𝒟\overline{{\cal D}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG that are not r𝑟ritalic_r-different. The proof of the following theorem is an easy consequence of the Ω⁢(D⁢log⁡(n/D))Ω𝐷𝑛𝐷\Omega(D\log(n/D))roman_Ω ( italic_D roman_log ( italic_n / italic_D ) ) lower bound for randomized protocols given in [KM93], the trivial lower bound Ω⁢(c)Ω𝑐\Omega(c)roman_Ω ( italic_c ), and Lemma 5.1.

Theorem 5.3

Let P𝑃Pitalic_P be any multi-RB protocol. 5.3 The multi-broadcast protocols

As mentioned in the Introduction, our multi-DB protocols make use of superimposed codes [EFF85, HS87, I97, CHI99]. In particular, we will use the following upper bounds [EFF85, KS64].

For any n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3italic_n ≥ 3 and for k≥2𝑘2k\geq 2italic_k ≥ 2,

The priorities will be used by the nodes to schedule the messages to send. In fact, every node stores the messages by means of a priority queue. The protocol multi-bb-broad-a⁢(n,Δ)multi-bb-broad-a𝑛Δ\mbox{\sc multi-bb-broad-a}(n,\Delta)multi-bb-broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Δ ) uses an (n,Δ+1)𝑛Δ1(n,\Delta+1)( italic_n , roman_Δ + 1 )-strongly-selective family ℱ={F1,F2,…⁢F|ℱ|}ℱsubscript𝐹1subscript𝐹2…subscript𝐹ℱ{\cal F}=\{F_{1},F_{2},\ldots F_{|{\cal F}|}\}caligraphic_F = { italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F | end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. It consists of a sequence of consecutive phases. Each phase consists of |ℱ|ℱ|{\cal F}|| caligraphic_F | time-slots. At the very beginning, the priority queues of the source nodes contain their broadcast messages, the other priority queues are empty. At the beginning of each phase, every node v𝑣vitalic_v with a non empty priority extracts from the queue the message mvsubscript𝑚𝑣m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of highest priority. At the j𝑗jitalic_j-th time-slot of the phase, node v𝑣vitalic_v acts according to the following rules.

- If the label of v𝑣vitalic_v belongs to Fjsubscript𝐹𝑗F_{j}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mvsubscript𝑚𝑣m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exists then v𝑣vitalic_v transmits mvsubscript𝑚𝑣m_{v}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
- In all the other cases, v𝑣vitalic_v acts as a receiver. If v𝑣vitalic_v receives a message that v𝑣vitalic_v has never received before, the message is enqueued, otherwise, the message is discarded.

Theorem 5.5

Protocol multi-bb-broad-a⁢(n,Δ)multi-bb-broad-a𝑛normal-Δ\mbox{\sc multi-bb-broad-a}(n,\Delta)multi-bb-broad-a ( italic_n , roman_Δ ) completes any r𝑟ritalic_r-broadcast operation within O⁢((D+c)⁢min⁡{n,Δ2⁢log⁡n})𝑂𝐷𝑐𝑛superscriptnormal-Δ2𝑛O((D+c)\min\{n,\Delta^{2}\log n\})italic_O ( ( italic_D + italic_c ) roman_min { italic_n , roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n } ) time-slots on any n𝑛nitalic_n-node graph of maximum eccentricity D𝐷Ditalic_D, maximum in-degree Δnormal-Δ\Deltaroman_Δ, and congestion c𝑐citalic_c.

Proof. Firstly, we prove the following

Claim 1 If a node v𝑣vitalic_v transmits a message during a phase t𝑡titalic_t then all the out-neighbours of v𝑣vitalic_v receive the message by the end of phase t𝑡titalic_t.

Proof. In fact, let u𝑢uitalic_u be any out-neighbour of v𝑣vitalic_v. By virtue of the (n,Δ+1)𝑛Δ1(n,\Delta+1)( italic_n , roman_Δ + 1 )-strongly selectivity of ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F, there is a time-slot of phase t𝑡titalic_t in which u𝑢uitalic_u acts as a receiver and v𝑣vitalic_v is the only node, among the in-neighbors of u𝑢uitalic_u (notice that these are at most ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ), that transmits. Hence, in that time-slot, u𝑢uitalic_u receives the message of v𝑣vitalic_v.

Now, we can show that all messages reach their destinations.


Claim 2 After a finite number of phases, any message m𝑚mitalic_m is received by all the nodes that are reachable from the source of m𝑚mitalic_m.

Proof. The proof is by induction on the distance ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ from the source. For ℓ=0ℓ0\ell=0roman_ℓ = 0 the claim is obvious. Let u𝑢uitalic_u be a node at distance ℓ+1ℓ1\ell+1roman_ℓ + 1 from the source. Consider an in-neighbour v𝑣vitalic_v of u𝑢uitalic_u at distance ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. From the inductive hypothesis, node v𝑣vitalic_v receives the message m𝑚mitalic_m. The first time this happens, m𝑚mitalic_m is enqueued in the priority queue of v𝑣vitalic_v. According to the protocol, at the beginning of each phase, node v𝑣vitalic_v extracts the message of highest priority and transmits it. Since there are less than r𝑟ritalic_r messages of priority higher than that of m𝑚mitalic_m and any message is enqueued at most once, it follows that v𝑣vitalic_v extracts and transmits m𝑚mitalic_m within at most r𝑟ritalic_r phases. Thus, from Claim 1 node u𝑢uitalic_u receives the message m𝑚mitalic_m.

The last step consists of showing that the messages cannot be delayed too much.

Claim 3 Assume that node u𝑢uitalic_u, at distance ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ from the source of a message m𝑚mitalic_m, receives m𝑚mitalic_m for the first time during phase ℓ+tuℓsubscript𝑡𝑢\ell+t_{u}roman_ℓ + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, during the first ℓ+tuℓsubscript𝑡𝑢\ell+t_{u}roman_ℓ + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT phases, u𝑢uitalic_u transmits at least tu−1subscript𝑡𝑢1t_{u}-1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 messages with higher priority than that of m𝑚mitalic_m.

Proof. The proof is by induction on the distance ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. For ℓ=0ℓ0\ell=0roman_ℓ = 0 the claim is obvious. Let u𝑢uitalic_u be a node at distance ℓ+1ℓ1\ell+1roman_ℓ + 1 and let v𝑣vitalic_v be the node at distance ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ from which u𝑢uitalic_u receives m𝑚mitalic_m for the first time. Let ℓ+tvℓsubscript𝑡𝑣\ell+t_{v}roman_ℓ + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the phase in which node v𝑣vitalic_v receives m𝑚mitalic_m for the first time. By inductive hypothesis, in the first ℓ+tvℓsubscript𝑡𝑣\ell+t_{v}roman_ℓ + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT phases, v𝑣vitalic_v transmits at least tv−1subscript𝑡𝑣1t_{v}-1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 messages of higher priority (than that of m𝑚mitalic_m). This fact and Claim 1 imply that, in the first ℓ+tvℓsubscript𝑡𝑣\ell+t_{v}roman_ℓ + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT phases, u𝑢uitalic_u receives from v𝑣vitalic_v a set M1subscript𝑀1M_{1}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of at least tv−1subscript𝑡𝑣1t_{v}-1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 messages of higher priority. Now, let k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0italic_k ≥ 0 be the number of phases during which the message m𝑚mitalic_m remains in the priority queue of v𝑣vitalic_v. This implies that v𝑣vitalic_v transmits a set M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of k𝑘kitalic_k further messages of higher priority before transmitting m𝑚mitalic_m. Let tu=tv+ksubscript𝑡𝑢subscript𝑡𝑣𝑘t_{u}=t_{v}+kitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_k; then node u𝑢uitalic_u receives m𝑚mitalic_m for the first time in phase ℓ+1+tuℓ1subscript𝑡𝑢\ell+1+t_{u}roman_ℓ + 1 + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notice that any message m𝑚mitalic_m has to reach nodes at distance at most D𝐷Ditalic_D from its source and there are less than c𝑐citalic_c messages of priority higher than m𝑚mitalic_m that collide with m𝑚mitalic_m. Hence, Claim 2 and Claim 3 imply that any message reaches its destinations in less than D+c𝐷𝑐D+citalic_D + italic_c phases. Since each phase requires O⁢(min⁡{n,Δ2⁢log⁡n})𝑂𝑛superscriptΔ2𝑛O(\min\{n,\Delta^{2}\log n\})italic_O ( roman_min { italic_n , roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n } ) time-slots (see Theorem. 5.4) the thesis follows. □□\Box□

6 Conclusions and open problems

The main contribution of this paper is that of providing explicit and strong connections between a set of old and new combinatorial tools and the issue of broadcast operations in radio networks of unknown topology. Thanks to such connections, we have obtained new lower and upper bounds on the completion time of this important operation. We believe that the concept of selectivity and that of r𝑟ritalic_r-different sequences can have further applications to other distributed models in which the local knowledge is extremely low. Some evidence of our opinion is also given by some previous results [Lin92] in which strongly-selective families have been used for the distributed coloring problem in unknown graphs.

As for specific research directions, the following ones appear to be the most relevant.

The upper bounds for the DB protocols are not efficiently constructible since the corresponding “small” selective families have been derived by using probabilistic arguments: it would thus be important to design an efficient deterministic algorithm that constructs such families.

The lower bounds for multi-DB (and multi-RB) protocols are consequences of the combinatorial lower bound Ω⁢(rlog⁡r⁢log⁡n)Ω𝑟𝑟𝑛\Omega(\frac{r}{\log r}\log n)roman_Ω ( divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_r end_ARG roman_log italic_n ) on the length of n𝑛nitalic_n pairwise r𝑟ritalic_r-different sequences given in Theorem 3.6. We do not know whether the latter is tight. As far as we know, the best upper bound is O⁢(r⁢log⁡n)𝑂𝑟𝑛O(r\log n)italic_O ( italic_r roman_log italic_n ). The deterministic upper bounds in Theorem 5.5 almost match the lower bound in Theorem 5.2, when Δ=O⁢(poly⁢log⁡n)Δ𝑂poly𝑛\Delta=O({\rm poly}\log n)roman_Δ = italic_O ( roman_poly roman_log italic_n ). An interesting future research goal is that of reducing the gap between upper and lower bounds for larger ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. To this aim, we believe that a generalization of the Ω⁢(rlog⁡r⁢log⁡n)Ω𝑟𝑟𝑛\Omega(\frac{r}{\log r}\log n)roman_Ω ( divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_r end_ARG roman_log italic_n ) lower bound to d𝑑ditalic_d-wise r𝑟ritalic_r-different sequences could give a stronger lower bound that also depends on ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ.

A further research direction is that of using the same combinatorial tools to investigate the issue of dynamical-fault tolerance in radio networks. Dynamical edge and node faults may happen at any instant, even during the execution of a protocol. Some results on this direction have been recently obtained in [CMS01c].
